answers.a: Yes—it's a moderately polar, aprotic solvent due to its ester carbonyl, though it’s less polar than acetone, acetonitrile, or alcohols.

answers.q: is ethyl acetate soluble in water
answers.a: Slightly—it's only moderately soluble in water (on the order of about 8–10% at room temperature).

answers.q: is ethyl acetate miscible in water
answers.a: No; it’s only partially miscible with water (limited mutual solubility rather than full miscibility).

answers.q: is ethyl acetate polar or nonpolar
answers.a: It is moderately polar and aprotic—more polar than hydrocarbons but less than acetone or alcohols.

answers.q: ethyl acetate can be prepared by an sn2 reaction
answers.a: Yes—acetate ion can alkylate primary ethyl halides via an SN2 reaction to form ethyl acetate, though industry more commonly uses acid-catalyzed esterification or catalytic routes from ethanol/acetaldehyde.
